Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Performance-Based Multi-Objective Optimization Framework to Define Innovative Structural Concepts and Support the Seismic Design of Critical Buildings

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award is to integrate performance-based design and multi-objective optimization into a single computational framework to support the seismic design of critical buildings. The emphasis is placed on critical buildings, such as acute care hospitals and emergency response centers, because these buildings play a key role in a community's response to an earthquake event and subsequent recovery. Disruption to the functionality of these buildings can have cascading effects resulting in significant societal losses. Although the focus here is on the seismic design of critical buildings, the integrated framework developed will be adaptable to all types of buildings and various natural hazards. Performance-based seismic design (PBSD) provides decision variables for post-event functionality or economic loss. However, the PBSD process is likely to lead to a satisfactory but not necessarily optimal design solution. Furthermore, the heuristic nature of the PBSD process does not provide understanding of the tradeoffs of robustness and cost-effectiveness. This research will pursue an integrated computational framework that simultaneously identifies innovative structural concepts and tradeoffs between conflicting design objectives to support decision-making.

The study will develop a computational framework that integrates probabilistic seismic performance assessment methodology and multi-objective algorithms. The integrated framework will be tested and validated in three phases. Each phase involves an increased level of mathematical modeling and computational complexity. In conjunction with the second phase, an improved hospital functionality model will be developed and incorporated into the framework to gain insights about how physical damage affects functionality and to identify innovative seismic protective system concepts that maximize post-event functionality while balancing conflicting design objectives, such as minimizing building cost. Following the third phase, a global variance-based sensitivity analysis will be performed on the integrated performance-based multi-objective optimization framework to understand how uncertainties in model factors propagate through the framework. The integrated educational activities are designed to address the need for understanding how to engineer complex systems at all levels of education. These activities include various techniques to reveal tradeoffs between conflicting objectives and techniques to identify balanced multiple conflicting objectives. The educational activities target groups ranging from K-12 students to K-12 educators to doctoral students and have been designed around engineering problems appropriate for each educational level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering is the application of principles of mathematics and science to design and develop products and processes to serve an intended function, while preserving the environment, economic operations, life, and safety. Thus, new knowledge and methods that advance the theory of design and improve design outcomes have the potential for broader beneficial impacts to both society and the profession of engineering. The outcomes of this research project include new knowledge and methods, published in the scientific and engineering literature as well as doctoral dissertations, that enable engineers to more efficiently analyze and design structural systems for earthquake ground shaking. Although the focus in this project is to demonstrate these new methods for the seismic design and performance based design of structural systems for buildings, these methods are sufficiently general and can be used to design and optimize a wide range of machines, structures, and other items.

Performance based design is an approach to design the components of a building based upon specific performance goals and objectives using accepted engineering tools, methodologies, and performance criteria. Performance criteria for seismic design are in general related to the damage and consequential losses that occur as a result of this damage in the form of casualties, direct and indirect economic costs, and costs associated with loss of service. The goal is to identify a design that meets the agreed upon performance thresholds and, in general, the performance thresholds are higher than the level of performance than would be achieved if the building were designed following minimum design requirements set forth in building codes. Historically, the relatively intensive effort required on behalf of the engineer to perform performance based design has precluded broad comparison of design concepts or optimization of the structural system to identify a design that not only achieves the performance thresholds but that minimizes damage and losses within specified constraints.

In this research, new knowledge and computational methods were developed that enable engineers to more effectively and efficiently, in comparison to current practices and design methods, optimize structural designs for buildings threatened by earthquake ground shaking that minimize damage and losses while rigorously accounting for material nonlinearity in the system and the uncertainty in the system's performance. In addition, computational methods were developed to efficiently optimize the topology of the structural systems subject to dynamic ground shaking accounting for the expected material nonlinearity in the structural elements that avoids divergence issues associated with conventional methods reported in the literature. Applying these methods to various design scenarios, it was demonstrated that optimal design solutions and tradeoffs among completing performance objectives could be successfully and more efficiently identified, while considering nonlinearity and uncertainty, in comparison to the available state-of-the-art design methodologies. Some key findings from these applications include: dominance of design alternatives can be made based on imprecise estimates of the performance based design criteria and that the imprecision can be sequentially reduced as a means to efficiently compare a large set of design alternatives while considering uncertainty when optimizing the design of the structural system; the suggested optimization method successfully avoids known divergence issues; material nonlinearity in the system should be considered in the optimization process since this type of nonlinearity can have meaningful impacts on the optimized design solution; and that considering material nonlinearity in the optimization process can lead to more efficient design solutions, that is designs that require less material and less direct cost, than if the nonlinearity were ignored. Other important outcomes of this project include the development, implementation, and dissemination of a multi-objective truss design activity for K-12 engineering and technology classes and the mentoring of female and minority doctoral students to completion of their degrees. With the K-12 multi-objective truss design activity, students learn about design objectives, for example minimizing deflections of the truss, learn there is more than one optimal design solution when considering multiple objectives, and also learn how to balance competing design objectives, such as minimizing the deflection of the designed truss versus minimizing the weight of the truss.
